text: And also of the son of the bondwoman will I make a nation, because he is thy seed.
text_kjv: And also of the son of the bondwoman will I make a nation, because he is thy seed.
text_niv: I will make the son of the maidservant into a nation also, because he is your offspring.”
text_esv: And I will make a nation of the son of the slave woman also, because he is your offspring.”
text_nlt: But I will also make a nation of the descendants of Hagar’s son because he is your son, too.”
text_msg: Regarding your maid's son, be assured that I'll also develop a great nation from him—he's your son too."
text_nasb: 'And of the son of the maid I will make a nation also, because he is your descendant.'
context: Genesis 21:13 occurs within the broader narrative of God's covenant with Abraham. Abraham, promised countless descendants, struggled with infertility. At Sarah's suggestion, he fathered Ishmael with Hagar, her Egyptian maidservant (Genesis 16). While Ishmael was initially considered Abraham's heir, God clarified that the covenant would be fulfilled through Sarah's son, Isaac (Genesis 17, 21). The cultural context surrounding concubinage is crucial. In ancient Near Eastern societies, a barren wife could offer her maidservant to her husband to produce offspring, legitimizing the child as her own. This was a socially acceptable, albeit complex, solution to ensure lineage. However, the dynamic between Sarah and Hagar became fraught with tension, as Hagar seems to have looked down on Sarah after conceiving. The tensions escalated following Isaac's birth, culminating in Sarah's demand that Hagar and Ishmael be expelled. This was a difficult decision for Abraham, highlighting the societal norms surrounding inheritance and the importance of a wife's status. The verse itself acknowledges Ishmael's lineage and guarantees a future nation from him, demonstrating God's sovereign grace extending beyond the covenant line. Understanding the social hierarchy, family dynamics, and promises already made to Abraham is crucial for interpreting the weight of this verse.
meaning: Theological meaning hinges on the sovereignty of God and the universality of His grace. While the Abrahamic covenant is central to God's redemptive plan through Isaac, this verse demonstrates God's care and provision extend beyond the chosen line. The phrase 'because he is thy seed' emphasizes that Ishmael, despite not being the covenant child, is still Abraham's offspring and thus deserving of blessings. This highlights God's impartiality and refusal to completely abandon any of His creation. Ishmael represents those outside the direct line of promise, those who may not be part of the central narrative of salvation history, yet still receive God's favor and protection. This can be seen as a prefigurement of God's eventual inclusion of the Gentiles into His covenant people through Jesus Christ. The verse challenges a narrow understanding of election. While God chooses specific individuals and nations for specific purposes, His love and concern extend to all. The promise to make Ishmael a nation does not negate the primacy of the covenant through Isaac; rather, it affirms God's power to bless and use even those who are not directly part of the Messianic line. It points to a wider view of God's kingdom, encompassing different peoples and nations, all ultimately accountable to Him. The assurance that Ishmael will father a nation signifies God's faithfulness to His word, even in situations arising from human impatience and flawed solutions.
application: Genesis 21:13 holds profound implications for modern Christians in several practical ways. Firstly, it calls us to expand our understanding of God's grace. We often focus on those within our church or Christian community, neglecting those outside the fold. This verse reminds us that God has a plan and purpose for all people, regardless of their background or beliefs. We should actively seek opportunities to show compassion and extend grace to those who may seem 'outside' the covenant. This involves challenging our prejudices and biases, recognizing the inherent worth and dignity of every individual as a creation of God. Secondly, the verse challenges us to address our own 'Ishmaels' – those unresolved issues, relational tensions, or consequences of past decisions that continue to affect us. Like Abraham, we may face situations born out of impatience or flawed human solutions. We need to trust in God's ability to bring good even from difficult circumstances. Acknowledging and repenting of our mistakes is essential, but dwelling on them is unproductive. God can redeem those situations and use them for His glory. Thirdly, we are called to pray for those outside our immediate circle, especially those of different faiths or cultural backgrounds. Just as God promised to make Ishmael a nation, we should believe that God desires good for all people and intercede on their behalf. This requires us to move beyond simple tolerance to genuine love and concern. Finally, it confronts the 'us vs. them' mentality that often permeates our society. God's promise to Ishmael reminds us that we share a common humanity and that God's love encompasses all nations. We are called to build bridges of understanding and reconciliation, promoting peace and justice in a world often divided by conflict and prejudice. We must strive to see others as God sees them – as valuable individuals created in His image, deserving of our love and respect.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for your unwavering grace and love that extends to all people. Forgive us for the times we have limited your love to those within our immediate circle, forgetting your promise to care for all of your creation. Help us to see every individual as valuable and deserving of compassion, regardless of their background or beliefs. Lord, give us the courage to reach out to those who are different from us, building bridges of understanding and reconciliation. Show us how to address the 'Ishmaels' in our own lives, trusting in your ability to redeem difficult circumstances. Empower us to be instruments of your peace, promoting justice and love in a world filled with division and conflict. May our lives reflect your generous and expansive love, demonstrating your care for all nations. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: No, it does not. While God fulfills His promise despite their actions, it doesn't condone their initial decision to have Ishmael through Hagar. God works in spite of, not because of, human error. It highlights God's grace within a complicated situation.
faqs.question: Q1: Does this verse justify the actions of Abraham and Sarah?

faqs.answer: The descendants of Ishmael are traditionally associated with Arab peoples. While the promise to make Ishmael a nation doesn't directly cause modern conflicts, it underscores the historical and complex relationship between different groups in the region. God's blessings don't negate free will or geopolitical forces.
faqs.question: Q2: How does this verse relate to modern-day conflicts in the Middle East?

faqs.answer: It signifies that Ishmael's descendants would grow into a numerous and influential people group, possessing their own territory, culture, and identity. God is promising a lasting legacy and impact on the world for Ishmael's lineage. This promise was demonstrably fulfilled.
faqs.question: Q3: What does 'make a nation' specifically mean in this context?

faqs.answer: No, this verse is a promise of national prosperity, not individual salvation. While God desires all people to be saved, salvation comes through faith in Jesus Christ. National blessing does not automatically equate to eternal salvation for everyone within that nation.
faqs.question: Q4: Is this verse a promise of salvation for all descendants of Ishmael?

faqs.answer: Christians should uphold their faith while demonstrating love and respect for all cultures. This means engaging in dialogue, seeking understanding, and recognizing the inherent dignity of every person, even when their beliefs differ. Love and truth must coexist.
